message.content: This question requires basic knowledge of the role of decomposers in the ecosystem. Dead organisms serve as a source of sustenance for decomposers. Decomposers break down the organic matter of dead organisms, recycling nutrients back into the ecosystem. Option (A) is incorrect because decomposers do not use dead organisms as a place to sleep. Option (B) is unrelated to the role of dead organisms for decomposers. Option (C) is also unrelated as decomposers do not form friendships with dead organisms.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of decomposers in an ecosystem. Decomposers, such as bacteria and fungi, feed on dead organisms and break them down into simpler substances. These decomposers derive their sustenance, or food, from the dead organisms. Option (A) is incorrect because decomposers do not use dead organisms as a place to sleep. Option (B) and (C) are unrelated to the role of decomposers in obtaining nutrients from dead organisms.

This question requires knowledge about the role of decomposers in an ecosystem. Decomposers feed on dead organisms and break them down into simpler substances in a process called decomposition. The dead organisms serve as a source of sustenance for decomposers. Option (A) is incorrect because while dead organisms may provide a habitat for some decomposers, they primarily serve as a food source. Option (B) and (C) are not related to the role of dead organisms for decomposers.

This question requires basic knowledge about the relationships in an ecosystem. Dead organisms provide sustenance for decomposers, which break down and consume the organic matter. Option (A) is incorrect because while dead organisms may provide a place for decomposers to live, they are primarily a source of food. Option (B) and (C) are not related to the role of dead organisms as a food source for decomposers.
